Hello Bill,

>> I'm not certain that today's JAX-RS offers much more than t=
oday's WCF in 
>> terms of REST support. If Glenn's team are going to do "R=
EST like they 
>> meant it" to paraphrase Guilherme, I don't think that JAX=
-RS is the 
>> right way to go.
> 
> But that's just an opinion. Or is ther=
e some technical criticism as well?

It's an opinion - I don't have any car=
efully gathered empirical evidence to back it up. However both WCF and JAX-=
RS avoid hypermedia which is pretty important for RESTful solutions. In oth=
er bits of that email, I pointed out that some JAX-RS compliant frameworks =
(e.g. Jersey) are now experimenting with hypermedia which makes them much m=
ore useful if the abstractions come out right.

In terms of technical criti=
que, I think JAX-RS comes out ahead of WCF because it's marginally easier t=
o TDD with it, and so much more of the framework is above the waterline rat=
her than buried down deep. However at this point both frameworks are simply=
 nicer programmatic interfaces atop a Web server, and both short-change cli=
ent-side developers (with JAX-RS again being better than WCF).

Since neith=
er has hypermedia support from the start, retrofitting it at this point may=
 result in horrid abstractions. That's why I'm broadly supportive of Glenn'=
s outreach and very supportive of the people behind Restfulie (as well as b=
eing encouraged by the steps the Jersey team are taking).

Jim
